The reason they would rather eat plant eating organisms is simple, as the the energy transfers from animal to animal only 10% of energy is transferred. Knowing that the animal that eats other animals  will have far less energy than an animal that eats plants. So the vulture has 1% of the energy from the plant, while the ducks and chickens have 10%. Now one could argue the animals don’t know that so how could they chose based on that, but that is where i would argue after millions of years of selection the animals who ate herbivores over other scavengers had more energy and were more likely to survive, making them the animals that survive, causing them to continue choosing to eat herbivores.

Many animals will eat "strange" things given the opportunity. Cows, squirrels, and deer will chew on carcasses and even eat small animals (baby birds are apparently a favorite snack for these mammals). Vultures will occasionally manage to catch and eat small live prey. And nearly all "carnivorous" mammals will scavenge if the carcass is up to their standards, and even occasionally eat some plant matter. Even though none of these animals are super well adapted for eating these things, they're not going to pass up free nutrients and energy when it's offered to them. The terms herbivore, omnivore, and carnivore are a lot more nuanced than people seem to realize.

Sooo.....often the limitation on predator populations is the other predators that prey on them. Cougars love raccoons and fox. Add wolves to Yellowstone and the coyote population is cut in half. Many orcas prey exclusively on sharks and dolphins. Primary killer of lions are other lions and they aren't shy about eating the vanquished. Plus lions have little tolerance for any other cats, hyenas or jackals. Mama bears spend alot of time defending themselves and their young from other bears. King cobras literally are specialized to wipe out their own kind and any other snakes they can lay their jaws on. Raccoons and possums routinely scavenge each other as do foxes and bobcats will prey on all of them. How picky are they when it comes to other predators? Add to that the low tolerance must predators display for their own kinds interloper who they routinely kill and often devour.

My grandfather used to tell a story about a family that came to eastern Texas during the Great Depression. They were trying to forage and hunt to help supplement their meager food supplies. Unfortunately, they didn’t know much about what was safe to eat directly from nature. They found some big fat buzzards (carrion eating birds) and proceeded to kill, cook, and eat them. Every single one of the family got really, really sick. Two of them died from it. So maybe the animals know something after all.
